author: By Tyler Kepner
title: An All-Day Journey Through Baseball’s Weird New Season
description: Deserved or not, the first weekend of M.L.B. brought some familiar, comforting scenes — as well as plenty of bizarre ones.
content: I sent a text to my high school English teacher the other day. He loves baseball, so I knew he would appreciate a photo of the Mets-Braves game at Citi Field, from my seat in the press box. He replied that he hadn’t expected to care much about a 60-game season, and yet there he was, on his couch, riveted to every pitch. Then he watched another game that night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: For French-Algerian Families, Virus Disrupts Cherished Summer Ritual
description: Holidays in Algeria are a cornerstone of the cross-cultural identity of many French people with roots there. This year, they are stuck at home, and the pain is acute: “It’s sacred for us to leave.”
content: TOULOUSE, France — Sitting around a table strewn with steaming cups of mint tea, a dozen  women were sharing memories of their summer holidays in their homeland, Algeria.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Sledding Athletes Are Taking Their Lives. Did Brain-Rattling Rides and High-Speed Crashes Damage Their Brains?
description: Not long ago, Pavle Jovanovic was among the world’s top bobsledders. In retirement, he battled mental illness and substance abuse. Were brain injuries the cause of his demise and that of others in his sport?
content: On May 3, Pavle Jovanovic, a former bobsledder, rigged a chain to a crane he and his brother kept in the shop of their family’s metal works in Toms River, N.J. He tied the loose end around his neck and hanged himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: The Virus Turns Midtown Into a Ghost Town, Causing an Economic Crisis
description: 7,500 workers are missing from a famous building. A food cart sells 10 hot dogs a day. The virus’s effect on one block could be an omen for the city’s future.
content: Editors and account managers at the Time & Life Building in Midtown Manhattan could once walk out through the modernist lobby and into a thriving ecosystem that existed in support of the offices above. They could shop for designer shirts or shoes, slide into a steakhouse corner booth for lunch and then return to their desks without ever crossing the street.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 25, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 25, 2020.
content: An article on Friday about a large DNA study that traced the violent history of American slavery referred imprecisely to some historical research. Historical records do exist showing that enslaved people were shipped directly from Nigeria to the United States, but not to the extent indicated by the new genetic evidence.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘We Were Somewhere in the 50s When We Noticed a Brass Quartet’
description: A face in the crowd, how to carry a rocking chair and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: The Difficulties and Delights of a Pandemic Wedding
description: The coronavirus turned our plans upside down, but in the end, the day was perfect.
content: NASHVILLE — When our oldest son got engaged last year at sunset on a beach in Spain, my husband and I cheered from half a world away. I write these words without hyperbole: We were truly as happy about this pending marriage as two human beings could possibly be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Wynonna Earp’ and a Manson Docuseries
description: The fan-favorite Syfy show returns for a fourth season. And “Helter Skelter: An American Myth” revisits the Manson murders.
content: WYNONNA EARP 10 p.m. on Syfy. This fantasy western series, based on the comic books by Beau Smith, has been described by its showrunner as “a combination of ‘Buffy the Vampire Slayer,’ ‘Justified’ and ‘Frozen.’” It follows the adventures of Wynonna Earp (Melanie Scrofano), a distant descendant of Wyatt Earp, who is tasked with protecting the remote plains town of Purgatory from demons. Wynonna does this using Wyatt’s enchanted gun, the Peacemaker, and with a little help from her sister Waverly (Dominique Provost-Chalkley) and Waverly’s girlfriend, Nicole Haught (Katherine Barrell), a Purgatory sheriff’s deputy. As the series enters its fourth season, the Earp curse has been broken, but Wynonna still has to rescue everyone she loves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Emily Cochrane
title: Trump Officials Float Idea of Narrow Bill to Extend Unemployment Benefits
description: The proposal on the eve of Republicans’ unveiling of a larger aid bill amounts to a concession that the two parties are unlikely to reach a deal before benefits expire.
content: Top Trump administration officials proposed on Sunday potentially short circuiting free-ranging stimulus talks with Democrats to rush through a much narrower bill prioritizing an extension of federal unemployment benefits that are set to expire this week for millions of Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keah Brown
title: ‘Disabled People Love Clothes Too’
description: But #disabledandcute influencers say the fashion industry has been slow to embrace them.
content: This article is part of a series exploring how the Americans With Disabilities Act has shaped modern life for people with disabilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Strange Bedfellows: Iran’s Ex-President Woos Saudi Crown Prince as Pen Pal
description: Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, known in the West for his Holocaust denial and disputed re-election in 2009, writes a warm letter to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, calling him a man of peace.
content: A former president of Iran, known in the West for speeches that assert the Holocaust was invented and that Israel should be erased from the map, has written a chummy letter to his country’s most ardent Arab foe: the crown prince of Saudi Arabia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheri Fink
title: ‘You Do the Right Things, and Still You Get It’
description: A Texas family tried to ward off the virus. But as cases in the state soared and debates about masks and distancing raged, there was only so much they could control.
content: HOUSTON — Elaine Roberts, a longtime bagger at a supermarket, tried to be so careful. She put on gloves and stopped riding the bus to work, instead relying on her father to drive her to keep their family safe. She wore masks — in space-themed fabrics stitched by her sister — as she stacked products on shelves, helped people to their cars and retrieved carts from the parking lot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Fighting False News in Ukraine, Facebook Fact Checkers Tread a Blurry Line
description: Facebook hired a Ukrainian group battling Russian disinformation to flag misleading posts. But critics say the fact checkers’ work veers into activism.
content: MOSCOW — To understand the complexity of policing online disinformation, consider the small Ukrainian fact-checking group StopFake.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Politicians and Masks
description: Readers criticize leaders who view mandatory mask-wearing as an infringement on rights. Also: President Trump and Ghislaine Maxwell; online voting for New York City; age and the pandemic.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Trump Backs Out of Throwing Pitch at Yankees Game
description: After saying he would do the ceremonial honor at a game on Aug. 15, causing a stir on social media, the president tweeted he would skip it to focus on combating the pandemic.
content: President Trump said he would no longer be throwing out the ceremonial first pitch before a Yankees game on Aug. 15 — days after he said he would be doing so, causing a political ruckus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Accusation’
description: An examination of the truth, in a moment when facts can seem malleable.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Fires and Pepper Spray in Seattle as Police Protests Widen Across U.S.
description: From Los Angeles to New York, protesters marched in a show of solidarity with demonstrations in Portland, Ore. In Seattle, they smashed windows and set fires. A shooting at a protest in Austin, Texas, left one man dead.
content: SEATTLE — Weeks of violent clashes between federal agents and protesters in Portland, Ore., galvanized thousands of people to march through the streets of American cities on Saturday, injecting new life into protests that had largely waned in recent weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Selma Helped Define John Lewis’s Life. In Death, He Returned One Last Time.
description: The body of John Lewis crossed the Edmund Pettus Bridge on Sunday, more than a half century after he helped change American history there.
content: SELMA, Ala. — On a different Sunday in Selma, this one more than five decades ago, John Lewis was a 25-year-old activist wearing a long tan coat and carrying a backpack, helping to marshal hundreds of demonstrators across the Edmund Pettus Bridge. They were bombarded by clouds of tear gas and swarmed by state troopers wielding clubs, one of which fractured Mr. Lewis’s skull.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Fiery, sweet and salty, Tejal Rao’s fried chicken biscuits are great to eat wherever you might be.
content: Good morning. Today I’d like to make these fried chicken biscuits (above) that Tejal Rao cooked up a few years ago and brought into the newsroom like a gift, fiery-sweet-salty little picnic sandwiches that brought laughter onto the floor. They’d be great to eat in a park this evening, on a porch or stoop or roof, at the beach or in the forest where the falling sun dapples the pine needles. They’d be great to eat in a tiny apartment with a fan doing overtime. They’d be great to eat anywhere, if chicken you eat. (You don’t? Try this chicken-fried tofu sandwich instead.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Goodbye, Extra $600 a Week
description: Federal aid programs will expire this week, but jobless numbers are rising again. It’s a perfect storm.
content: It’s a big week ahead in Washington, where Congress will hash out the fate of jobless benefits for over 30 million people as the coronavirus rages on. Here’s what else you need to know in business and tech as we roll into Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Premier League Calls It a Year, 352 Strange Days After It Began
description: A remarkable year in England ended with Aston Villa saved, Watford and Bournemouth relegated and the big clubs pretty much where everyone expected them to be.
content: LEICESTER, England — Those final few minutes, the ones upon which an entire season rests, do something strange to time. The clock seems to slow, each second clawing and scratching for its moment before it yields to the next. But each is so pregnant with meaning, or with the possibility of meaning, that even in these moments that last an age, it can be hard to keep up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Trump’s Nakedly Political Pandemic Pivot
description: This is how the president operates when he is desperate and in trouble.
content: After mocking people for wearing masks, refusing to publicly wear one himself and holding rallies and gatherings where social distancing was not required, President Trump has shifted his tone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: 9 Great Olivia de Havilland Movies to Stream
description: The actress, who died on Sunday at age 104, won two Oscars and took on risky parts that challenged her patrician facade.
content: Best known for her turn as Melanie Hamilton in “Gone With the Wind” and her swashbuckling adventures with Errol Flynn, Olivia de Havilland specialized in playing aristocrats of virtue, though her work would get more varied as her career progressed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Peter Green, Fleetwood Mac’s Founder, Is Dead at 73
description: One of England’s finest blues guitarists, he wrote most of the group’s early songs. But he left the group after taking LSD, saying he wanted to change his life.
content: Peter Green, the English guitarist and singer who founded Fleetwood Mac, died on Saturday. He was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio and Aimee Ortiz
title: Small Plane Crashes Into Backyard in Utah City, Killing 3
description: Three people died in the crash, including a 9-month-old, an official said. Four others were injured.
content: A small plane with six people aboard crashed into a backyard in a residential section of a city in Utah on Saturday afternoon, killing three people and sending a fireball hundreds of feet into the air, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Théophile Larcher
title: Volunteer Confesses to Starting Fire at Nantes Cathedral
description: French prosecutors have charged the man, a Rwandan refugee, with arson. He had been questioned and released earlier in the investigation.
content: PARIS — A Rwandan refugee who volunteered at the 15th-century cathedral in Nantes, France, has confessed to setting a fire that severely damaged the interior of the church this month, his lawyer said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Slimmed-Down Baseball on TV Has Broadcast Workers Worried
description: Could changes to telecasts made during the coronavirus pandemic become permanent?
content: Major League Baseball’s abbreviated 60-game season will look a bit different on television this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: As a Teenager, I Hated Johnny Carson. Then Came the Pandemic.
description: As a teenager, I thought his ‘Tonight Show’ was a bland, uncool relic. Now I appreciate his deadpan humor and the loose weirdness of his interviews.
content: In the last few months, at the end of news-packed days, as the noise of my cooped-up children gives way to the calmer sounds of sirens and fireworks, I have found myself uninterested in seeing any of the current late-night hosts transform the horrors of the world into jokes. I get my fill on Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa, Vanessa Friedman and Elizabeth Paton
title: Everlane’s Promise of ‘Radical Transparency’ Unravels
description: Employees past and present are challenging management, saying the company’s ethical image was an illusion.
content: Michael Preysman, a founder and the chief executive of Everlane, a fashion brand that targets the ethically minded with minimalist basics, stood onstage in May 2019 at the Copenhagen Fashion Summit and preached the gospel of his company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Yes, Fake News Is a Problem. But There’s a Real News Problem, Too.
description: In “Ghosting the News,” Margaret Sullivan writes about the consequences of local newspapers closing across the country.
content: What do you call it when a hedge fund buys a local newspaper and squeezes it for revenue, laying off editors and reporters and selling off the paper’s downtown headquarters for conversion into luxury condos or a boutique hotel?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: How Remote Work Will Create Economic Winners and Losers
description: Working from home is about more than just Slack and Zoom. It could increase wages for some, but also inequality and insecurity.
content: When the pandemic hit and tens of millions of American workers suddenly redeployed to their basements and living rooms, it was easy to imagine that their workdays would unfold roughly as before, with communication tools like Slack and Zoom substituting for face-to-face interactions (and maybe with slightly greater multitasking opportunities).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Berkvist
title: Olivia de Havilland, a Star of ‘Gone With the Wind,’ Dies at 104
description: Ms. de Havilland, a classic Hollywood beauty, built an illustrious film career punctuated by a successful fight to loosen studios’ grip on actors.
content: Olivia de Havilland, an actress who gained movie immortality in “Gone With the Wind,” then built an illustrious film career, punctuated by a successful fight to loosen the studios’ grip on contract actors, died on Sunday at her home in Paris.  She was 104 and one of the last surviving stars of Hollywood’s fabled Golden Age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch and Christina Morales
title: Hawaii Braces for ‘Triple Threat’ of Hurricane Douglas
description: The National Hurricane Center on Sunday warned that the storm could bring “damaging winds, flooding rainfall and dangerously high surf” to the state.
content: Hawaii residents on Sunday were bracing for the arrival of Hurricane Douglas, which was threatening to bring sustained winds near 85 miles per hour and torrential rainfall in some areas, forecasters said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle and Raphael Minder
title: Quarantine Order Blindsides Britons Returning From Spain
description: Britain’s sudden decision to make travelers from Spain self-isolate for 14 days caught many vacationers by surprise — including the transportation secretary.
content: LONDON — Often criticized for a slow response to the coronavirus, the British government moved quickly this weekend to impose a quarantine on anyone arriving from Spain, after a spike in Covid-19 cases there.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Federal Agents’ Aggression in Portland Stretches Legal Limits
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 26, 2020.
content: “This is not creeping authoritarianism. The authoritarianism is here.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: A Liberal Town Built Around Confederate Generals Rethinks Its Identity
description: In Lexington, Va., where Robert E. Lee and Stonewall Jackson are buried, people are reassessing the town’s ties to a legacy that symbolizes slavery and oppression.
content: LEXINGTON, Va. — It’s a short drive in Lexington from a home on Confederate Circle past the Stonewall Jackson Memorial Cemetery and over to the Robert E. Lee Hotel, where locals like to stop for a drink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘In These Uncertain Times’ Review: Love, Loss and Zoom
description: Source Material presents a postmodern approach to talking about grief and isolation in quarantine.
content: “You OK?”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Testing Results Take Too Long, U.S. Official Concedes
description: Florida has now recorded more cases than New York. Britain orders travelers from Spain into 14 days of isolation, upending vacation plans for thousands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Your Coronavirus Antibodies Are Disappearing. Should You Care?
description: Declining antibody levels do not mean less immunity, experts say. Besides, two widely used tests may detect the wrong antibodies.
content: Your blood carries the memory of every pathogen you’ve ever encountered. If you’ve been infected with the coronavirus, your body most likely remembers that, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Elijah Walker
title: Coronavirus, Hurricane Hanna, Regis Philbin: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: States Issue Warnings About Seed Packets From China
description: Agriculture officials in Louisiana, Kansas, Virginia and Washington State are urging residents not to plant the seeds, which were mailed in pouches featuring Chinese characters.
content: Officials in at least four states are urging residents to report any unsolicited packages of seeds that appear to have been sent from China, warning that they might be invasive or otherwise harmful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Houston Beats Chicago to Win N.W.S.L. Title
description: The Dash won the Challenge Cup final, the culmination of a monthlong tournament held behind closed doors in Utah.
content: SANDY, Utah — Sophie Schmidt scored on an early penalty kick and Shea Groom added a stoppage-time goal to give the Houston Dash a 2-0 victory over the Chicago Red Stars in the National Women’s Soccer League’s Challenge Cup final on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Taylor Swift, a Pop Star Done With Pop
description: On “Folklore,” a quarantine album made largely with Aaron Dessner from the National, she swerves away from her last few releases, embracing atmospheric rock — and other characters’ points of view.
content: The song that catapulted Taylor Swift from too-cool-for-country phenom to the-world-is-not-enough pop supernova was “We Are Never Ever Getting Back Together,” the debut single from her fourth album, “Red,” in 2012. The first of her songs to top the Billboard Hot 100, it deployed country references as a tease on the way to an ecstatically saccharine, unmistakably pop hook — a universal anthem of I’m over it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Cay Johnston
title: Mason Gaffney, Who Argued for Taxing Only Land, Dies at 96
description: He was at the forefront of a tax-policy movement based on the ideas of Henry George, which helped spark the Progressive movement in the 19th century.
content: As Mason Gaffney bicycled to a Boy Scout meeting in 1940, a chauffeur-driven car clipped him, leaving him with injuries that kept him bedridden for months. During his convalescence his mother, appreciating his restless intellectual curiosity, gave him books to read, including complex tax policy textbooks in which he learned about Henry George, whose late-19th-century ideas helped sparked the Progressive movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Hurricane’s Choice for Texans: Shelter From the Virus or the Storm
description: Hurricane Hanna prompted officials and residents alike to rethink how and where to ride out a dangerous storm during a pandemic.
content: CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas — Bartt Howe’s boat was his refuge from the pandemic. Battling diabetes and H.I.V., he knew that catching the coronavirus as well could kill him, so he had been living alone on the docked boat for three months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Well, Hello to You, Too
description: Alan Arbesfeld opens our solving week in a very friendly way.
content: Administrivial alert:  The Times is working on an issue with downloadable puzzle PDFs.  We will make them available here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong, Mihir Zaveri and William K. Rashbaum
title: Inside the Violent and Misogynistic World of Roy Den Hollander
description: He was known for his hatred of women and frivolous lawsuits. Then he killed the son of a New Jersey federal judge before taking his own life, officials said.
content: Roy Den Hollander sounded bitter and angry when he bumped into a former rugby teammate in December at a library in Manhattan. He said he was so sick from a rare cancer that he could die at any moment, wondering aloud if he should sue his doctor for malpractice.
source.name: The New York Times

title: You Say We Need a Revolution?
description: Readers caution against radical change, though one disagrees.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: North Korea, U.S.-China, Olivia de Havilland: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know today.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judith Heumann and John Wodatch
title: We’re 20 Percent of America, and We’re Still Invisible
description: Disabled Americans are asking for true inclusion.
content: This month as the 30th anniversary of the Americans With Disabilities Act approached, we asked two prominent figures in the disability rights movement, Judy Heumann and John Wodatch, where they thought the United States stood in its quest to secure full rights for people with disabilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Montgomery and Manny Fernandez
title: Garrett Foster Brought His Gun to Austin Protests. Then He Was Shot Dead.
description: The police in Austin, Texas, have not identified the motorist who fatally shot a protester after driving his car in the direction of marchers.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — It was not unusual for Garrett Foster to be at a protest against police brutality on a Saturday night. And it was not out of character for him to be armed as he marched.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘The Persians’ Review: Aeschylus’s Ancient Portrait of Defeat
description: This staging by the National Theater of Greece was broadcast live on Saturday from the amphitheater of Epidaurus.
content: There is not much action, barely even a plot, in “The Persians.” People just mill about, talking (admittedly rather intensely) about events (admittedly of the tragic kind) that happened far away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: Don’t Ban TikTok. Make an Example of It.
description: There is plenty the U.S. government could do to ensure that TikTok acts responsibly without getting rid of it altogether.
content: For a while, it seemed that TikTok might dodge the techlash. After all, what could be problematic about a short-form video app featuring a bunch of teenagers and 20-somethings doing choreographed dances, roller skating, hanging out in influencer mansions and cutting into photorealistic cakes?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 26, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 26, 2020.
content: An article this weekend on Page 5 about the director Krzysztof Warlikowski, who is staging “Elektra” at the Salzburg Festival, misspells the surname of a Polish actor. He is Jacek Poniedzialek, not Pondiezialek.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleanor Lutz
title: Meet the 3 Spacecraft Heading to Mars This Summer
description: Three missions are headed to Mars this summer. They carry a wide array of instruments to explore the red planet.
content: Three missions are headed to Mars this summer. They carry a wide array of instruments to explore the red planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheri Fink, Emily Rhyne, Emma Cott and Ben Laffin
title: How Coronavirus Ravaged One Houston Family
description: Coronavirus numbers have shot up across the country. A family in Texas, a virus hot spot, describes how the illness quickly spread among them and hospitalized both parents.
content: Coronavirus numbers have shot up across the country. A family in Texas, a virus hot spot, describes how the illness quickly spread among them and hospitalized both parents.
source.name: The New York Times
